pandion

Since posts are disappearing anyway, let me add a new one.
 
 Now we all know that I am made in the image and likeness of God and since God is perfect, that image and likeness must also be, as a logical consequence, perfect. To state less would mean that God is not perfect. So if I am the image and likeness of God, then either I am perfect or God is not.
 
 "But the sin of Adam and Eve caused mankind to fall," you will assert. Then does this mean that I am no longer in the image and likeness of the Creator? Has that Creator become less than perfect or have I evolved away from the perfection of the first man so that if I stand up the weight of my body presses down on my lower spinal disks and slowly destroys them? So does the sin of Adam merit the introduction of weakness in these disks (and how can a perfect God create such weakness?).
 
 So is it Adam's sin or possibly an old injury that began my trouble? Should I curse Adam because in 60 some years of walking around one of my disks disintegrated (not ruptured mind you - literally disintegrated) and a second was well on the way to doing the same? Or should I blame a perfect God who is a really bad engineer - isn't that a contradiction? But any mechanical engineer can point out scads of engineering flaws in the human spine - a lot less if we walked on all fours. Where is the perfection of the image of God?
 
 Anyway, my perfect image of God has cost me years of pain with a more recent almost crippling of my right leg followed by 7 hours of surgery (including 11 inches of surgical incision - front and back) to correct my perfection by removing the debris left by two disintegrating disks and inserting two steel frame disks and screwing two steel rods into my vertebrae in the gutter on either side of my spine. The muscles that used to lie in those gutters are sutured over the top, and they are not happy with their new position.
 
 My perfect back, designed by a perfect God, in his perfect image has now been fixed and I should be able to walk without a back brace or a walker in only a few more weeks.
 
 How is this a perfect design in the image and likeness of a perfect God - or was this the result of the evolution of a skeleton system made for walking on four legs that is somewhat less than perfect for bipedal locomotion?

post_info.post_title: The results of the image and likeness of a perfect God

Black Phoenix

well....let's see my Bible says:
 
 Gen. 1:27
 
 "So God created man in his own image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created them."
 
 This verse states very cleary several things.
 
 1. God is a man....well not exactly a man...but with a masculine identity...
 
 2. Man came first, Women second.
 
 3. God CREATED them, not allowed them billions of years to evolve....
 
 4. In his own image.......I don't see a perfect anywhere in that verse....hmm.....God is perfect yes....but the text no where states that God created a PERFECT man in his own PERFECT image....that would thus be God simply cloning himself.....making another God....what would be the point of that?......God created man in a more abstract manner I believe...he wanted unique individuals...not a bunch of replicas of himself.....also it didn't state exact image....we know God isn't a female correct?....and it would be safe to assume God doesn't have reproductive organs....because he is a Holy God....
 
 So I'm sorry for your pains and trials you've had in your life.....but you're understanding of God is a little off I believe.....
pandion
Actually, your theology is screwed. You are claiming that a perfect God is capable of being imperfect. You're theology is silly.

 I think you can forget about God the super "engineer" on this one: your final question contains a necessary and sufficient condition to explain the case.

Since posts are disappearing anyway, let me add a new one.
 
 Now we all know that I am made in the image and likeness of God and since God is perfect, that image and likeness must also be, as a logical consequence, perfect. To state less would mean that God is not perfect. So if I am the image and likeness of God, then either I am perfect or God is not.

 think of it as a photocopy of a check for a million dollars. yes the copy is in the image and likeness of the original check, but it is not the check. you cannot cash the photocopy, regardless of how accurate the copy is, it is not the check, only an image of it. that doesn't mean anything is "wrong" with the original, and it doesnt mean that the copy has to have all the properties and function of the original. its just an image
billsco

God walks on all fours. Trust me on this one, I have it on good authority. We sinned when we stood up and reached for the fruit. emoticon_wow 
 
 Seriously, I hope your surgery restores you to a pain-free, high quality lifestyle. Best wishes to you pandion.
unkerpaulie

Anyway, my perfect image of God has cost me years of pain with a more recent almost crippling of my right leg followed by 7 hours of surgery (including 11 inches of surgical incision - front and back) to correct my perfection by removing the debris left by two disintegrating disks and inserting two steel frame disks and screwing two steel rods into my vertebrae in the gutter on either side of my spine. The muscles that used to lie in those gutters are sutured over the top, and they are not happy with their new position.

 i'm truly sorry to hear about your pain and i hope your recovery comes soon. 
 
 i think the most popular justification people give for their atheism (i'm not saying youre an atheist) is "if God exist, why is their so much pain/suffering/[negativity]". this justification apeals to the majority of "layman" ateists more than anything else
 
 last week my wife took our 2-year old son to the store. on the way back, just as they were coming to the entrance of our building, she let go of his hand so he could run ahead inside. instead, he ran down the sidewalk, between 2 parked cars and into the street. at the same time a car was coming up the street, didnt even see our son, and never even slowed down. when my wife ran out to get him, he had stayed close to the parked car and out of the way. had he run into the street he would have vry likely been killed. this somehow miraculous escape from tragedy has strengthened my wife's faith in God
 
 strange enough, if (God forbid) things had gone wrong and our son had stopped in the middle of the street, it is very likely that she would question God's existence.
 
 this is also the reason why atheism is more like a religion. through emotional experiences, rather than deduction and reasoning, people decide whether God exists or not. it also has to do with perception, since there are christians who suffer afflictions similar to yours, and it only strengthens their faith.
 
 yes, emotional stimuli affect all of us, usually with more impactful effects than physical trauma. and yes, we expect a God of spiritual power to appeal to us at least in the emotional sense (since it is the only form of contact believers have with God anyway), and if God cannot be there on an emotional level, then is he really there at all?
 
 i think its incorrect to determine that God exists (or not) solely on the tragedy that we experience. a miraculous escape from death does not strengthen the case for God's existence. likewise, a devastating tragedy does not strengthen the case for his non-existence
pandion

unkerpaulie
 
 I think your analogy breaks down with a little thought. If I have a check for a million dollars and I take it to a copy machine and make a copy, I am quite aware that the copy will not be perfect. There is an imperfect mechanical divice between the check and the copy. Or are you saying that God has a big imperfect copy machine that he jumps into and out pops an imperfect copy.
 
 My thought was that God was the direct agent of creation (without the use of intervening mechanical devices), and being a perfect Being incapable creating imperfection (for then He would not be God), all of His creation would be as perfect as He is.
 
 So does this perfect God have a spine that is a plethora of engineering disasters?

 an image is not the original. a photo of you is not you, its an image of you. the image cannot be or replace the original, and isnt intended to

 It is curious how lately christians have been telling me that being an aethiest (which I am), is a religion.
 The above post is a good example of this misunderstanding.
 First - the lack of a religion is NOT a religion.
 Second, I'll simply disagree with your statement. Observation, reasoning, and deduction is exactly what leads me to understand that there is no god, and that religion is merely an attempt to explain what we have not yet been able to reason out. As our knowledge increases, our need for a god decreases, and we can begin to see through the emotional fog of religion that keeps us in ignorance.
unkerpaulie

 i am not saying that all atheists rely on emotional justification. but many do. the real way to determine God's existence (or lack of) is through observation and rational deduction (which is impossible anyway), not because of personal emotional ups and downs. 
 
 religion essentially sells the idea that humans need some form of emotional rationale. since no religion can appeal to the physical senses, they usually appeal to the feelings (and by extension, personal convictions) of its members. however, emotions cannot determine truth, and is completely subjective
 
 dont get me wrong, emotional justification is vital. its what gives us motivation and a sense of responsibility, and without emotions we cannot care or love. emotions and reason are both needed in balance for humans to function in the type of society we live in
 
 however, my point is that emotions alone cannot build a case for theism or atheism. when such is the case, it is no different from a religion
Alan Ryan

however, my point is that emotions alone cannot build a case for theism or atheism. when such is the case, it is no different from a religion

 
 I think bringing "emotions" into the question of whether God exists or not tends to cloud the issue a bit.
 Isn't the essence of atheism a rational enquiry which concludes that in the absence of any credible evidence, there is no reason to believe in God ? An emotional attachment to "non-belief" would be irrelevant (and irrational).
unkerpaulie

I think bringing "emotions" into the question of whether God exists or not tends to cloud the issue a bit.
 Isn't the essence of atheism a rational enquiry which concludes that in the absence of any credible evidence, there is no reason to believe in God ? An emotional attachment to "non-belief" would be irrelevant (and irrational).

 i agree. but you cannot deny that it is still the most common reason for atheism. i would daresay that the majority of people that dont believe God exists feel that way "because of all the evil in the world" (or some related variation of this). i know for a fact that it is the most commonly raised argument for atheism
Alan Ryan

i agree. but you cannot deny that it is still the most common reason for atheism. i would daresay that the majority of people that dont believe God exists feel that way "because of all the evil in the world" (or some related variation of this). i know for a fact that it is the most commonly raised argument for atheism

 You may be right about the "reasons" people give for being an atheist: it's very difficult to reconcile a "loving God" with all the suffering in this world. But, strictly speaking, that sort of "reason" is not relevant to the question of whether God exists or not.
Waxy

i agree. but you cannot deny that it is still the most common reason for atheism. i would daresay that the majority of people that dont believe God exists feel that way "because of all the evil in the world" (or some related variation of this). i know for a fact that it is the most commonly raised argument for atheism

 
 For a fact? How?
 
 I think you're using a pretty broad brush here, and quite frankly, I don't agree, I'm denying it. :p
 
 Granted that this board attracts those more on the "intellectual" end of the spectrum, but I haven't seen or heard of that reason being used on this board beyond maybe in passing, and only rarely as the reason elsewhere.
 
 I think your assertion really undermines the amount of thought, reason, and education that is behind most atheists and agnostics "beliefs". That might be the most common flippant answer that a person would give if asked the question "Why don't you believe in God", but I strongly doubt it forms the basis of their reasoning for not believing.

 I'm not sure about that. Since we aethiests don't hold any regular get togethers, I can't really speak to the majority view. However, my own view of what constitutes evil is simply that which harms society (and by extension, it's members). No god required, no anti-god required.
 
 I think that the reasoning of "because of all the evil in the world" is simply an argument against the christian (or similar) god. Evil gods exist in many religions, and evil is seen as a result of their actions.

 Well, the type of atheism you are talking about here requires faith.
 If you say "I know there is no god," this statement requires faith.
 You have not observed anything that would lead you to reason or deduce that there must not be a god. 
 The presence of religion has nothing to do with this faith and it's not a religion, just a gross assumption with no "proof."
 
 
I think bringing "emotions" into the question of whether God exists or not tends to cloud the issue a bit.
 Isn't the essence of atheism a rational enquiry which concludes that in the absence of any credible evidence, there is no reason to believe in God ? An emotional attachment to "non-belief" would be irrelevant (and irrational).

 This is more accurate, but let me modify it a bit.
 Without evidence there is no reason to conclude that there MUST be a god.
 A lack of evidence does not ensure that there is no god, just that we can't assume that there is.

 First, I did not say that "I know there is no god." What I said (here I am expanding and clarifying my original statement "I understand that there is no god") or meant to say is simply that there is no evidence to support the existence of such a thing as god.
 As to your second statement; you may want to rephrase it. The inability to prove a negative is an invalide argument. You cannot "prove" that invisible fairies do not live in your attic. You can, however, believe that they do. The belief that they do requires faith, the understanding that they do not results from lack of any evidence that they do.

 All I know is that I don't know one way or the other.

 an emotional "reason", of course. it's the exactly "reason" why theists believe that God exists. such a reason doesnt tell you, the external observer, anything about the existence of God, since emotions are strictly internal and subjective

 well, i must admit, this is the most common reason i have personally encountered from atheists. i know i have to be very careful with sweeping generalizations around you lol. it may be more accurate to say, from what i've seen, most atheists believe God doesnt exist mainly because of the presence of gratituous and abundant evil in the world. constant tragedy and pain afflicting innocent people is the most common reason i've heard why God cannot exist
 
 as far as rational evidence against the existence of God, there is nothing more than the vague definitions of God, and the lack of expected results, to work with. its hardly conclusive evidence, but its as rational as you can get under the circumstances
 
 besides, disbelieving in God after observing the inhumanity and extremity of violence and evil in the world is by no means flippant. God's only responsibility on earth as it is right now is to keep the conditional promises of the bible (although even these promises are written in very vague language). for example, if you are righteous and prayer, your prayers will be answered. if God is bound by a promise to do something once a condition is met, but he doesnt do it, this is actually more valid reason to believe a God that keeps biblical promises doesnt exist. (of course, more likely you will believe that it was something you did wrong, not that God isnt doing his part). in a nutshell, when tragedy happens to people that expect God's protection, and when people are disappointed from expecting of God, it is a very compelling reason for them to think God simply isnt there

This site is the most comprehensive I've found on atheism, as well as having an indispensible listing of the common logical fallacies:
 
 The Atheism Web
 http://www.infidels.org/news/atheism/miscellany.html
 
 Nowhere on the site is the "amount of evil in the world" given as a reason for atheism. In fact, the word "evil" only appears twice, in examples of fallacies.
MrWriteLA

Some atheists have used the existence of evil as an argument against the existence of God, but on the evidence it can scarcely be shown to be the reason for most atheists becoming atheists.
 
 Here are links to essays on both logical and evidentiary arguments of this type:
 http://www.infidels.org/library/modern/nontheism/atheism/evil.html
 http://www.infidels.org/library/modern/nontheism/atheism/evil-logical.html

Maybe you'll have to clear up the difference between "understanding" and "knowing." I know what I think the difference is, but I need to know what you mean when you say "I understand that there is definitely no god."
 
 Personally, I understand that we have no verification one way or another.
 All I know is that I don't know one way or the other.

 Again you've made a slight alteration to my post (adding the word definitly). It's subtle, but it does affect the meaning.
 Let me see if I can be more clear on the difference between understanding and knowing.
 I'll start with webster's definition (excerpted) of "understand" and "understanding":
 
 2 : to accept as a fact or truth or regard as plausible without utter certainty <we understand that he is returning from abroad<
 3 : to interpret in one of a number of possible ways[/B]
 4 : to supply in thought as though expressed <"to be married" is commonly understood after the word engaged<
 intransitive senses
 1 : to have understanding : have the power of comprehension
 2 : to achieve a grasp of the nature, significance, or explanation of something
 3 : to believe or infer something to be the case
 Look closely at the highlighted entries.
 Now compare that with the most common definition of "know":
 
 1 a (1) : to perceive directly : have direct cognition of  
 
 The difference is "inference by reason vs. knowledge by direct perception"
 
 This is as close to humanly possible to knowing the truth about god. A thing that does not exist cannot be directly percieved (although the inability to directly percieve it is evidence that it does not exist).
 
 Hope this clears things a little.
